titleStmt.title: The vvise-woman of Hogsdon. A comedie. As it hath been sundry times acted with great applause. Written by Tho: Heyvvood.
Wise-woman of Hogsdon
Wise-woman of Hogsdon.
titleStmt.author: Heywood, Thomas, d. 1641.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by M. P[arsons] for Henry Shephard, and are to be sold at his shop in Chancerie-Lane, at the signe of the Bible, between Serjeants-Inne and Fleet-street,

note.p: Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

div.p: As it hath been sundry times Acted with great Applause.
Printed by M. P. for Henry Shephard, and are to be sold at his Shop in Chancerie-Lane, at the Signe of the Bible, between Serjeants-Inne and Fleet-Street. 1638.

list.item: Sir Harry, A Knight, who is no piece of a Scholler.
Sir Boniface, an ignorant Pedant, or Schoolmaster.
The Wisewoman of Hogsdon, who beares the name of the Dramma.
A Countryman, Clyent to the Wisewoman.
A Kitchin-mayd, and two Citizens Wives, that come to the Wisewoman for counsell.

div.head: Actus primus, Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter, as newly come from play, foure young Gentlemen, Master Chartley, Master Sencer, M. Boyster; and Master Haringfield.

sp.speaker: Chartley.
sp.p: PRice of my life: now if the Devill have bones, these Dyce are made of his. Was ever such a cast seene in this Age? Could any Gull in Europe (saving my selfe) fling such a cast?

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Eye.

sp.speaker: Chartley.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Yes.

lg.l: But I say no: I have lost an hundred pound,
And I will have my saying.
I have lost an other hundred, Ile have mine.
Ey, yes, I flung a worse: a worse by oddes.
I cry you mercy sir, loosers may speake,
Ile not except gainst you: but let me see
Which of these two that pocket up our Cash
Dares contradict me?
Sir, not I:
I say you have had bad casting.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: So say I.

lg.l: I say this Hatt's not made of wooll
Which of you all dares say the contrary?

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: It may bee tis a Beaver.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: Very likely so: 'tis not Wooll, but a plaine Beaver.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: 'Tis Wooll ,but which of you dares say so? would faine picke a quarrell with them, to get some of my money againe; but the slaves slaues they have got it are too wise to part with it.
I say it is not blacke.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: So say wee too.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Tis false: his Cap's of Wooll, 'tis blacke, and Wooll, and Wooll and blacke.

lg.l: I have nought to say to losers.
Have I nothing left to set at a Cast? Ey finger,
Must you be set in gold, and not a jot of silver in my purse?
A Bale of fresh Dice. Hoe, come at this Ring.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Fie M. Chartley, 'tis time to give over.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: That's the Winners phrase: Hold me play; Or hee that hath uncrown'd me, Ile take a speedie order with him.

lg.l: Fresh dice: this Iewell I will venture more
Take this and all. Ile play in spight of lucke.
Since you will needs; trip for the Dice.
I see it is hard to goe a winner from this company.
The Dice are mine:
This Diamond I valew at twentie markes:
Ile venture it at a throw.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: 'Tis for you.

lg.l: Then at all. All's mine. Nay M. Boyster,
I barre you: let us worke upon the winners.
Gramercy Sinks: Nay, though I owe you no quarrell, yet you must give mee leave to draw.
I had rather you should draw your sword,
Then draw my money thus.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Againe sweet Dice: nay I barre swearing, Gentlemen, let's play patiently. Well, this At the Candlesticke, so—

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Now Dice at all. To tho, quoth the Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Here's precious lucke.

lg.l: Why Via. I thinke tis Quicke-siluer;
It comes and goes so fast: there's life in this.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: Hee passes all with Trayes.

lg.l: With Trayes, how say by that
Oh hee's old dogge at Bowles and Trayes.
Lend me some money: be my halfe one Cast.
Ile once out-brave this Gamester with a throw
So now the Dice are mine, wilt be my halfe?

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: I will.

lg.l: Then once Ile play the Franck Gamester.
Let mee but see how much you both can make,
And Ile cast at all, all, every Crosse.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Now blesse us all, what will you every Crosse?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: I will not leave my selfe one Crosse to blesse me.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I set.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: And so doe I.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Why then at all. How!

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Nay, sweare not, lets play patiently.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Damn'd Dice: did ever Gamester see the like?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Never, never.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Was ever knowne such Casting?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Drunke nor sober, I ne're saw a man cast worse.

lg.l: Ile prove this Hat of mine an Helmet.
Which of you here dares say the contrary?

sp.speaker: Chart:
sp.p: As faire an Helmet as any man in Europe Needs to weare.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Chartley, thy Hat is blacke.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Vpon better recollection, 'tis so indeed.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: I say 'tis made of Wooll.

lg.l: True, my losing had tooke away my Senses,
Both of Seeing and Feeling: but better lucke
Hath brought them to their right temper.
But come, a pox of Dice; 'tis time to give over.
All times are times for winners to give over,
But not for them that lose. Ile play till midnight,
But I will change my lucke.
Come, come, you shall not.
Give over: tush give over: doe I pray,
And chuse the Fortune of some other hower:
Let's not like debosht fellowes, play our Clothes,
Belts, Rapiers, nor our needfull ornaments:
'Tis childish, not becomming Gentlemen.
Play was at first ordayn'd to passe the time;
And sir, you but abuse the use of Play,
To employ it other wise.
You may perswade me—
For once Ile leave a looser.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Then come put on your Helmet; let's leave this abominable Game, and find out some better Exercise. I cannot indure this chafing when men loose.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: And there's not a more testie waspish Companion then thy selfe when thou art a looser, and yet thou must bee vexing others with, Play patiently Gentlemen, and lets have no swearing.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: A signe that I can give good counsell better than take it: but say, Where be the prettiest wenches, my hearts?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Well remembred, this puts mee in mind of an appointment I had with a Gentlewoman of some respect.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: I have you sir, I have you; but I think you will never have her: 'tis Gratiana the Knights daughter in Gracious Street. Have I toucht you?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: You have come somewhat neere me, but toucht me not. Master Haringfield, will you beare me company thither? Have you seene the Gentlewoman, M. Chartley?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Never sir.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: How have you heard of her?

lg.l: That shee hath, as other women have,
That she goes for a Mayd, as others doe, &c.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: I can assure you, shee is a proper Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Then if she have you, she is like to have a proper Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: You should tell them so that know it not. Adjew Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: I am glad yet they goe so lightly away.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: What will you doe M. Boyster?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Somewhat.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: You will not acquaint me with your businesse.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: No: I am in love, my head is full of Proclamations. There is a thing call'd a Virgin. Nature hath shewed her Art in making her. Court her I cannot, but Ile doe as I may.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Doe you goe, or stay sir?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Goe.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: You before, Ile follow. He thinkes with his blunt humour, to enter as farre as I with my sharpe: No, my true Trojan, no: There is a faire sweet modest rogue, her name is Luce: with this Dandiprat, this pretty little Apes face, is yon blunt fellow in love; and no marvell, for shee hath a Browe bewitching, Eyes ravishing, and a Tongue enchanting: And indeed shee hath no fault in the world but one, and that is, shee is honest: and were it not for that, shee were the onely sweet Rogue in Christendome. As I live, I love her extreamely, and to enjoy her would give any thing: But the foole stands in her owne light, and will doe nothing without Marriage: but what should I doe marrying? I can better indure Gives, than Bands of Matrimonie. But in this Meditation, I am glad I have wonne my Money againe. Nay, and shee may be glad of it too: for the Girle is but poore, and in my pockett I have layd up a Stocke for her, 'tis put to use alreadie. And if I meete not with a Dyce-house, or an Ordinary by the way, no question but I may increase it to a summe. Well, Ile unto the Exchange to buy her some prettie Noveltie: That done, Ile visite my little Rascall, and sollicite instantly.

div.head: Actus primus, Scena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Luce in a Semsters shop, at worke vpon a lac'd Handkercher, and Joseph a Prentice.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Where is my Father? Ioseph.

lg.l: Mistresse, above,
And prayes you to attend below a little.
I doe not love to sit thus publikely:
And yet upon the traffique of our Wares,
Our provident Eyes and presence must still wayte.
Doe you attend the shop, Ile ply my worke.
I see my father is not jelous of me,
That trusts mee to the open view of all.
The reason is, hee knowes my thoughts are chast,
And my care such, as that it needes the awe
Of no strict Overseer.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Yonder's Luce. Save thee.

lg.l: And you too, sir, y'are welcom; want you ought,
I pray, in which our Trade may furnish you?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Ioseph, shew the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Tis heere that I would buy.

lg.l: What doe you meane sir, speak, what ist you lack?
I pray you wherefore doe you fixe your eyes
So firmely in my face? what would you have?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Thee.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Mee?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Yes, thee.

lg.l: Your pleasure is to jest, and so I take it.
Pray give me leave sir, to intend my worke.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: You are fayre.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You flout mee.

lg.l: You are, goe too, you are,
Ide vexe him that should say the contrary.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Well, you may say your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I love thee.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Oh Sir!

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: As I live, I doe.

lg.l: Now as I am a true Maid,
The most religious oath that I dare sweare,
I hold my selfe indebted to your love:
And I am sorry there remaines in mee,
No power how to requite it.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Love mee, prethee now, doe if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Prethee, if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Yet aske thine heart, and see what may be done.

lg.l: In troth I am sorry you should spend a sigh
For my sake unrequited, or a teare;
Ey, or a word.
'Tis no matter for my words, they are not many,
And those not very wise one's neither.
Yet I beseech you spend no more in vaine.
I scorne you not; Disdaines as farre from mee,
As are the two Poles distant: therefore Sir,
Because I would not hold you in suspence,
But tell you what at first to trust unto,
Thus in a word, I must not fancie you.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Must-not?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I cannot, nor I may not.

lg.l: I am gone:
Thou hast given me, Luce, a Bone to gnaw upon.

sp.speaker: Luce.

lg.l: Alas, that Beauty should be sought of more
Then can injoy it: might I have my wish,
I would seeme faire but onely in his eye,
That should possesse mee in a Nuptiall tye.

sp.stage: Enter yong Master Chattley, with Gloues, Ring, Purse, etc..

lg.l: Morrow Luce; In exchange of this kisse, see
what I have brought thee from the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: What meane you Sir, by this?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Guesse that by the circumstance, here's a Ring, weare't for my sake; twenty Angels, pocket them you foole; come, come, I know thou art a Maid, say nay, and take them.

lg.l: Sweet Master Chartley, doe not fasten on me,
More then with ease I can shake off: your Gift
I reverence, yet refuse; and I pray tell mee,
Why doe you make so many Errands hither?
Send me so many Letters? fasten on me
So many favours? what's your meaning in't?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Harke in thine eare, Ile tell thee; nay heare me out, is't possible so soft a body should have so hard a soule? Nay now I know my penance, you will be angry, and schoole me for tempting your modesty: a figge for this modesty, it hinders many a good man from many a good turne, & that's all the good it doth. If thou but knewst, Luce, how I love thee, thou wouldst be farre more tractable. Nay, I barre chiding when you speake, Ile stop thy lips if thou dost but offer an angry word, by this hand Ile do't, and with this hand too. Goe to now, what say you?

lg.l: Sir, if you love me, as you say you doe,
Shew me the fruits thereof.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: The stocke I can, thou maist see the fruits hereafter.

lg.l: Can I beleeve you love mee, when you seeke
The ship wrack of mine Honour?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Honour! there's another word to flap in a mans mouth: Honour! what shouldst thou and I stand upon our Honour, that were neither of us yet, Right Worshipfull?

lg.l: I am sorry Sir, I have lent so large an eare
To such a bad discourse; and I protest
After this houre, never to doe the like.
I must confesse, of all the Gentlemen
That ever courted mee, you have possest
The best part in my thoughts: but this course language
Exiles you quite from thence. Sir, had you come,
In stead of changing this mine honest name
Into a Strumpets, to have honoured me
With the chaste Title of a Modest Wife;
I had reserv'd an eare for all your suits:
But since I see your rudenesse finds no limit,
I leave you to your lust.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: You shall not, Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Then keepe your tongue within more moderate bounds.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: I will, as I am vertuous, I will: I told you, the second word would be Marriage. It makes a man forfeit his Freedome, and makes him walke ever after with a Chaine at his heeles, or a Iack-an-Apes hanging at his elbow: Marriage is like Dedalus his labyrinth, and being once in, there's no finding the way out. Well, I love this little property most intollerably, and I must set her on the Last, though it cost me all the shooes in my shop. Well Luce, thou seest my stomacke is come downe; thou hast my heart already, there's my hand.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: But in what way?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Nay, I know not the way yet, but I hope to find it hereafter, by your good direction.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I meane, in what manner? in what way?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: In the way of marriage, in the way of honesty, in the way that was never gone yet: I hope thou art a Maid, Luce.

lg.l: Yes Sir, and I accept it; in exchange
Of this your hand, you shall receive my heart.

sp.speaker: Chartley.
sp.p: A bargaine, and there's earnest on thy lips.

lg.l: Ile call my Father, Sir, to witnesse it:
See, here hee comes.

div.stage: Enter her Father, a plaine Citizen.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Father, save you, you have happened of an untoward Son-in-Law; here I am, how doe you like mee?

lg.l: Sir, I was nearer then you were aware,
And over-heard both summe and circumstance.
Then I perceive you are an old Eves-dropper:
But what doe you thinke of it, Father?
I entertaine the motion with all love,
And I rejoyce my Daughter is preferr'd,
And rais'd to such a match; I heard the contract,
And will confirme it gladly: but pray Sir,
When shall the merry day be?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Marry, even to morrow by that we can see; my, wee'l lose no more time, Ile take order for that.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Stay but a moneth.

sp.speaker: Chart
sp.p: A moneth I thou canst not hire me too't. Why Luce, if thou beest hungry, canst thou stay a moneth from meat? Nay, if I see my diet before me, I love to fall too when I have a stomacke. Here, buy thee a new Smocke; let's have a new Bed too, and looke it be strong: there's a box of Rings and Jewels, lay them up. Ha sirra; me thinkes the very name of Wedlock hath brought me to a Night-cap already, and I am growne civill on the sudden. There's more money for Dishes, Platters, Ladles, Candlesticks, &c. as I shall find them set downe in the Inventorie.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: But whom shall wee invite unto the Wedding?
sp.stage: Enter 2d. Luce, a yong Countrey Gentlewoman, in the habit of a Page, and overheares their discourse.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Ey, thereby hangs a Tale, we will have no more at our marriage, but my selfe, to say, I take thee Luce; thou to say, I Luce take thee Robin: the Vicar to put us together, and you Father, to play the Clerke, and cry Amen.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Your reason for that.

sp.speaker: Chartl.
sp.p: I would not for a world it should bee knowne to my Friendes, or come to my Fathers care. It may bee tenne thousand pounds out of my way for the present: therefore this is my conceite, Let us bee marryed privately, and Luce shall live like a Mayde still, and beare the Name. Tis nothing Luce: it is a common thing in this age to goe for a Mayde, and bee none. Ile frequent the house secretly: feare not Girle, though I revell abroad a dayes, Ile bee with thee to bring a nights, my little Whiting Mopp.

lg.l: But so I may incurre a publike scandall,
By your so oft frequenting to my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Scandall? what scandall? Why to stopp the mouth of all scandall, after some few dayes doe I appeare in my likenesse, married man and honest hous-keeper, and then what becomes of your scandall? Come, send for Mr. Vicar, and what we doe, lets doe suddenly.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Cold comfort for me.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: If you purpose to be so privately married, I know one excellent at such an exployt: are you not acquainted with the Wise-woman of Hogsdon?

sp.speaker: Chartley.
sp.p: O the Witch, the Beldame, the Hagge of Hogsdon.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: The same, but I hold her to bee of no such condition. I will anone make a steppe thither, and punctually acquaint her with all our proceedings: shee is never without a Sir Iohn at her elbow, ready for such a stratagem.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Well, bee't so then.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
Heigh hoe: have I disguis'd my selfe, and stolne out of the Countrey thus farre, and can light of no better newes to entertaine mee? Oh this wild-headed wicked Chartley, whome nothing will tame. To this Gallant was I poore Gentle-woman betroathed, and the Marriage day appoynted: But hee out of a fantastick and
giddy humour, before the time prefixed, posts up to London. After him come I thus habited, and you see my welcome, to bee an eare-witnesse of his second Contracting. Modestie would not suffer mee to discover my selfe, otherwise, I should have gone neere to have marred the match. I heard them talke of Hogsdon, and a Wise-woman, where these Aymes shall bee brought to Action. Ile see if I can insinuate my selfe into her service: that's my next project: and now good luck of my side.

div.head: Actus secundus, Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter the Wise-woman and her Clyents, a Countrey-man with an Urinall, foure Women like Citizens wives, Taber a Serving-man, and a Chamber-mayd.

lg.l: Fie, fie, what a toyle, and a moyle it is,
For a woman to bee wiser then all her neighbours?
I pray good people, presse not too fast upon me;
Though I have two eares, I can heare but one at once.
You with the Vrine.

sp.speaker: Countryman.
sp.p: Here forsooth Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: And who distill'd this water?

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: My wives Limbeck, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: And where doth the paine hold her most?

sp.speaker: Countr
sp.p: Marry at her heart forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Ey, at hor heart, shee hath a griping at her heart.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: You have hit it right.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Nay, I can see so much in the Vrine.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Iust so much as is told her.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Shee hath no paine in her head, hath shee?

sp.speaker: Countrym
sp.p: No indeed, I never heard her complaine of her head.

lg.l: I told you so, her paine lyes all at her heart:
Alas good heart! but how feeles shee her stomacke?

sp.speaker: Countrym.
sp.p: O queasie, and sicke at stomacke.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Ey, I warrant you, I thinke I can see as farre into a Mill-stone as another: you have heard of Mother Notingham, who for her time, was prettily well skill'd in casting of Waters: and after her, Mother Bombye; and then there is one Hatfield in Pepper-Alley, hee doth prettie well for a thing that's lost. There's another in Coleharbour, that's skill'd in the Planets. Mother Sturton in Goulden-lane, is for Forespeaking: Mother Phillips of the Banke-side, for the weaknesse of the backe: and then there's a very reverent Matron on Clarkenwell-Green, good at many things: Mistris Mary on the Banke- side, is for recting a Figure: and one (what doe you call her) in Westminster, that practiseth the Booke and the Key, and the Sive and the Sheares: and all doe well, according to their talent. For my selfe, let the world speake: harke you my friend, you shall take—

lg.l: 'Tis strange the Ignorant should be thus fool'd.
What can this Witch, this Wizard, or old Trot,
Doe by Inchantment, or by Magicke spell?
Such as professe that Art should be deepe Schollers.
What reading can this simple Woman have?
Tis palpable grosse foolery.

sp.speaker: Kitchin.
sp.p: Now friend, your businesse?

lg.l: I have stolne out of my Masters house, forsooth,
with the Kitchin-Mayd, and I am come to know of you,
whether it be my fortune to have her, or no.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: And what's your suit, Lady?

sp.speaker: Kitchin.
sp.p: Forsooth, I come to know whether I be a Maid or no.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Why, art thou in doubt of that?

sp.speaker: Kitchin.
sp.p: It may bee I have more reason then all the world knowes.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Nay, if thou com'st to know whether thou beest a Maid or no, I had best aske to know whether I be with child or no.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Withdraw into the Parlour there, Ile but talke with this other Gentlewoman, and He resolve you presently.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Come Sisty, if shee cannot resolve thee, I can, and in the Case of a Mayden-head doe more then shee, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: The Wom.
sp.p: Forsooth I am bold, as they say.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: You are welcome Gentlewoman.—

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: I would not have it knowne to my Neighbours, that I come to a Wise-woman for any thing, by my truly.

sp.speaker: Wisewom.
sp.p: For should your Husband come and find you here.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: My Husband woman, I am a Widdow.

sp.speaker: Wisewom.
sp.p: Where are my braines? 'tis true, you are a Widdow; and you dwell, let me see, I can never remember that place.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: In Kentstreet.

sp.speaker: Wisewom.
sp.p: Kentstreet, Kentstreet! and I can tell you wherfore you come.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Why, and say true?

sp.speaker: Wisewom.
sp.p: You are a Wagge, you are a Wagge: why, what doe you thinke now I would say?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Perhaps, to know how many Husbands I should have.

sp.speaker: Wisewom.
sp.p: And if I should say so, should I say amisse?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: I thinke you are a Witch.

sp.speaker: Wisewom.
sp.p: In, in, Ile but reade a little of Ptolomie, and Erra Pater; and when I have cast a Figure, Ile come to you presently.
Now Wagge, what wouldst thou have?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: If this were a Wisewoman, shee could tell that without asking. Now me thinkes I should come to know whether I were a Boy or a Girle; forsooth I lacke a service.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: By my Fidelitie, and I want a good trusty Lad.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Now could I sigh, and say, Alas, this is some Bawd trade-falne, and out of her wicked experience, is come to bee reputed wise. Ile serve her, bee't but to pry into the mysterie of her Science.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: A proper stripling, and a wise, I warrant him; here's a penie for thee, Ile hire thee for a yeare by the Statute of Winchester: prove true and honest, and thou shalt want nothing that a good Boy—

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Here Wise-woman you are out againe, I shall want what a good Boy should have, whilst I live: well, here I shall live both unknowne, and my Sex unsuspected. But whom have wee here?
sp.stage: Enter Master Haringfield, and Chartley halfe drunke.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Come Haringfield, now wee have beene drinking of Mother Red-caps Ale, let us now goe make some sport with the Wise-woman.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: Wee shall be thought very wise men, of all such as shall see us goe in to the Wise-womans.

sp.speaker: Chartley.
sp.p: See, heere shee is; how now Witch? How now Hagge? How now Beldame? You are the Wisewoman, are you? and have wit to keepe your selte warme enough, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Out thou knave.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: And will these wild oates never be sowne?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: You Inchantresse, Sorceresse, Shee-devill; you Madam Hecate, Lady Proserpine, you are too old, you Hagge, now, for coniuring up Spirits your selfe; but you keepe prettie yong Witches under your roofe, that can doe that.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: I, or my Family conjure up any Spirits! I defie thee, thou yong Hare-brain'd—

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: Forbeare him till he have his Senses about him, and I shall then hold thee for a Wise-woman indeed.: otherwise, I shall doubt thou hast thy name for nothing. Come friend, away, if thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Away you old Dromadary, Ile come one of these nights, and make a racket amongst your SheeCatterwaullers.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: I prethee let's be civill.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Out of my sight, thou Shee-mastiffe.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Patience, sweet Mistris.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Now blesse mee, hee hath put mee into such a feare, as makes all my bones to dance, and rattle in my skin: Ile be reveng'd on that swaggering companion.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Mistris, I wish you would, hee's a meere Mad-cap, and all his delight is in mis-using such reverent Matrons as your selfe.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Well, what's thy name, Boy?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I am even little better than a Turn-broach, for my name is Iacke.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Honest Iacke, if thou couldst but devise how I might cry quittance with this cutting Dicke, I will goe neare to adopt thee my Sonne and heire.

lg.l: Mistris, there is a way, and this it is;
To morrow morning doth this Gentleman
Intend to marry with one Mistris Luce,
A Gold-smiths Daughter; doe you know the Maid?
My Daughter, and a prettie smug fac't Girle.
I had a note but late from her, and shee meanes
To be with me in th'evening; for I haue bespoke
Sir Boniface to marry her in the morning.
Doe but prevent this Gallant of his Wife,
And then your wrongs shall be reveng'd at full.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Ile doe't, as I am Matron; Ey, and shew him a new tricke for his learning.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Morrow.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Y'are welcome Sir.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Art wise?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Hee should be wise, because hee speakes few words.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: I am as I am, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Canst conjure?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Oh that's a foule word! but I can tell you your Fortune, as they say; I have some little skill in Palmistry, but never had to doe with the devill.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: And had the devill never any thing to doe with thee? thou look'st somewhat like his damme. Looke on mee canst tell what I ayle?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Can you tell your selfe? I should guesse, you be mad, or not well in your wits.

lg.l: Th'art wise, I am so; men being in love, are mad,
And I being in love, am so.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Nay, if I see your complexion once, I thinke I can guesse as neare as another.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: One Mistris Luce I love, knowst thou her, Grannam?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: As well as the Beggar knowes his Dish. Why shee is one of my Daughters.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Make her my wife, Ile give thee forty pieces.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Take them Mistris, to be reveng'd on Chartley.

lg.l: A bargain, strike me luck, cease all your sorrow,
Faire Luce shall be your Bride betimes to morrow.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Th'art a good Grannam; and, but that thy teeth stand like hedge-stakes in thy head, I'de kisse thee.

lg.l: Pray will you in; come hither lacke, I have
A new tricke come into my head, wilt thou
Assist mee in't?
If it concerne the crossing of the marriage with
Mistris Luce, Ile do't what e're it be.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Thou shalt be tyred like a woman; can you make a curtesie, take small strides, simper, and seeme modest? me thinkes thou hast a womans voyce already.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Doubt not of me, Ile act them naturally.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: I have conceited, to have Luce married to this blunt Gentleman; shee mistaking him for Chartley, and Chartley shall marry thee, being a Boy, and take thee for Luce. Wilt not be excellent?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Oh super, super-excellent!

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Play but thy part, as Ile act mine, Ile fit him with a Wife, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: And a Wife Ile warrant him.
sp.stage: Exeunt. Enter Old Sir Harry, and his man Taber.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Ha, then thou sawest them whispering with my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: I saw them, if it shall please you, not whisper, but—

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: How then, thou knave?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Marry Sir Knight, I saw them in sad talke; but to say they were directly whispering, I am not able.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Why Taber, that sad talke was whispering.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Nay, they did not greatly whisper, for I heard what was said, and what was said, I have the wit to keepe to my selfe.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: What said the unthrift, Taber, tell me knave? Tell me, good knave, what did the unthrift say?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: I am loath to be call'd in question about men and womens matters, but as soone as ever he saw your Daughter, I heard what was spoke.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Here sirra, take thy Quarters wages afore-hand, and tell me all their words, and what their greeting was at their first encounter; hold thine hand.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Thankes, Noble Sir, and now Ile tell you. Your daughter being walking to take the aire of the fields, and I before her; whom should wee meet just in the nicke?

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Iust in the nicke, man?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: In the high-way I meant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Ha, and what conference past betwixt them, Taber?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
As well as my Pipe can utter, you shall know Sir.
This Gentleman meeting with my yong Mistris full butt; imagine you were she, and I yong Master Sencer; now there you come, and here I meet you; he comes in this manner, and put off his hat in this fashion.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: I, but what said hee?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Be with you, faire Gentlewoman; and so goes quite away, and scarse so much as once look'd backe: and if this were language to offer to a yong Ladie, judge you.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: But spake hee nothing else?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Nothing as I am true.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Why man, all this was nothing.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Yes Sir, it was as much as my Quarters wages afore-hand.
sp.stage: Enter Master Sencer, Master Haringfield, and Gratiana.

lg.l: Here are two Gentlemen with great desire,
Crave conference with my Father: here he is,
Now Gallants, you may freely speake your minds.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Save you Sir, my name is Sencer; I am a Northampton-shire Gentleman, borne to a thousand pound Land by the yeare: I love your Daughter, and I am come to crave your good-will.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Have you my Daughters, that you covet mine?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: No Sir, but I hope in time I shall have.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: So hope not I. Sir, Sir, my Daughters yong, and you a Gentleman unknowne, Sencer? ha, Sencer? O Sir, your name I now remember well, 'tis rank't 'mongst thrifts, dicers, swaggerers, and drunkards: were not you brought before me, some moneth since, for beating of the Watch, by the same token, I sent you to the Counter?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: I confesse my selfe to have beene in that action, but note the cause, Sir: you could not have pleasur'd mee so much, in giving mee a piece of gold, as at the same time to helpe me to that Counter.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Why Sir, what cause had you to beat the Watch, and raise a midnight tumult in the streets?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Nay, but heare mee, sweet Sir Harry: Being somewhat late at Supper at the Miter, the doores were shut at my Lodging, I knock't at three or foure places more, all were a-bed, and fast: Innes, Tavernes, none would give me entertainment. Now, would you have had me dispair'd, and layne in the streets? No, I bethought me of a tricke worth two of that, and presently devis'd, having at that time a charge of money about me, to be lodg'd, and safely too.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: As how, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Marry thus: I had knockt my heeles against the ground a good while, knew not where to have a Bed for love nor money. Now what did I? but spying the Watch, went and hit the Constable a good sowse on the Eare, who provided me of a lodging presently; and the next day, being brought before your Worship, I was then sent thither backe againe, where I lay three or foure dayes without controule.

lg.l: O, y'are a Gallant! is that Gentleman
A Suitor too?
I am a Suitor in my friends behalfe,
No otherwise: I can assure you, Sir,
He is a Gentleman discended well,
Deriv'd from a good house, well quallify'd,
And well possest; but that which most should move you,
Hee loves your Daughter.
But were I to chuse,
Which of these two should please my fancie best,
I sooner should affect this Gentleman,
For his mad carriage, and his faire discourse,
Then my hot Suitor; Ruffians I detest:
A smooth and square behaviour likes mee best.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: What say you to me, Lady.

sp.speaker: Gratian.
sp.p: You had best aske my Father what I should say.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Are you angry, sweet Lady, that I ask't your Fathers consent?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: No, if you can get his consent to marry him, shall it displease mee?

lg.l: Indeed you therein much forget your selfe,
To sound her Father e're you tasted her.
You should have first sought meanes for her good-will,
And after compast his.
He can prevaile with neither: Gentlemen,
If you will come to revell, you are welcome;
If to my Table, welcome; if to use mee
In any gratefull Office, welcome too:
But if you come as Suitors, there's the doore.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: The doore!

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: I say the doore.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Why Sir? tell not me of your doore, nor going out of it, your companie is faire and good, and so is your Daughters; Ile stay here this twelve-moneth, e're Ile offer to trouble your doore.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Sir, but you shall not. Taber! where's that knave?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Why Sir, I hope you doe not meane to make us dance, that you call for a Taber.

lg.l: Nay Master Sencer, doe not urge the Knight,
Hee is incenst now, chuse a fitter houre,
And tempt his love in that: old men are testie,
Their rage, if stood against, growes violent;
But suffred and forborne, confounds it selfe.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Where's Taber?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: At hand, noble Master.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Shew them the doore.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: That I will, and take money too, if it please them.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Is thy name Taber?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: I am so eclip't Sir.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: And Taber, are you appointed to give us Iacke Drum's entertainment?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Why sir, you doe not play upon me.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
Though I cannot, yet I have knowne an Hare
that could. But Knight, thou doest not forbid us the House.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Yes, and forewarne it too.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: But by thy favour, wee may chuse whether we will take any warning or no. Well, farewell olde Knight, though thou forbidst mee thine house, Ile honour thee, and extoll thee; and though thou keepst mee from thy Daughter, thou shalt not hinder mee to love her, and admire her: and by thy favour, sometimes to see her: A Catt may looke at a King, and so may I at her. Give me thine hand, Knight, the next time I come into thy company, thou shalt not onely bid me welcome, but hire mee to stay with thee, and thy daughter.

lg.l: When I doe that, enjoy my full consent,
To marry Graciana.
Tis a match, strike mee lucke:
Wife that may bee, farewell: Father in law that
Must bee, adiew. Taber, play before, my friend
And I will daunce after.
When I receive thee gladly to mine house,
And wage thy stay, thou shalt have Gratiana,
Doubt not, thou shalt. Here's a strange Humourist,
To come a wooing. Taber, are they gone?

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: I have plaid them away, if it please your Worship; and yonder at the doore attends a Schoolmaster, you sent for him, if you remember, to teach my little yong Master and Mistris.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: A proper Scholler, pray him to come neare.
sp.stage: Enter a pedanticall Schoolmaster, Sir Boniface.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Eques Honoratus: Aue fulutatus: non uideo quid est in Tergo, sed salve bona virgo.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Sir, you may call me nick-names: if you love me, speake in your Mother-tongue; or at the least, if Learning be so much ally'd unto you, that Latine unawares flowes from your lips: to make your mind familiar with my knowledge, pray utter it in English: what's your name?

lg.l: Sit faustum tibi omen.
Ile tell you my Nomen.
Will you tell it to no men.
Ile entertaine none e're I know their names:
Nay, if you be so dainty of your name,
You are not for my service.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Intende uir nobilis.

lg.l: Not for twenty Nobles:
Trust me, I will not buy your name so deare.
O Ignorantia! what it is to deale with stupidity?
Sir Henry, Sir Henry, heare me one word,
I see, Precepter legit, uos vero negligitis.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: I thinke he saith we are a companie of fooles, and Nigits, but I hope you shall not find us such, Master Schoolmaster.

lg.l: Friend, friend, to cut off all vaine circumstance,
Tell me your name, and answer me directly,
Plainly, and to my understanding too,
Or I shall leave you: here's a deale of gibberish.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Vir bone.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Nay, nay, make me no bones, but do't.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Then in plaine vulgar English I am call'd, Sir Boniface Absee.

lg.l: Why this is somewhat like, Sir Boniface,
Give me thine hand, thou art a proper man,
And in my judgement, a great Scholler too:
What shall I give thee by the yeare?
Ile trust, Sir, to your generosity;
I will not bargaine, but account my selfe
Mille & mille modis, bound to you.
I cannot leave my Mils, they'r farm'd already,
The stipend that I give, shall be in money.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Sure Sir, this is some Miller that comes to undermine you, in the shape of a Schoolmaster.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: You both mistake the Scholler.

lg.l: I understand my English, that I know;
What's more then Moderne, doth surpasse my reach.
Sir Boniface, come to me two dayes hence,
You shall receive an answer; I have now,
Matters of some import that trouble me,
Thou shouldst be else dispatch't.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Sir Boniface, if you come to live in our house, and be a Familist amongst us, I shall desire you better acquaintance, your Name and my Phisnomy should have some consanguinitie, good Sir Boniface.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Quomodo vales, quomodo vales.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Goe with you to the Ale-house? I like the motion well; Ile make an excuse out of doores and follow you. I am glad yet, we shall have a Good-fellow come into the house amongst us.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Vale vir Magno.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: You shall not have me at Saint Magnes, my house is here in Gracious-street.

lg.l: I know it, sweet Knight, I know it.
Then virgo formosa, & Domine gratiose valete.
Ey, in Gracious-street you shall heare of me,
Sir Bonif. He shall instruct my children; and to thee,
Faire Gratiana, reade the Latine tongue,

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Who, shall Sir Bawdy-face?

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Sir Boniface, you foole.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: His name is so hard to hit on.

lg.l: Come Daughter, if things fall out as I intend,
My thoughts shall peace have, and these troubles end.

div.head: Actus tertius, Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter the second Luce, which was Iack in womans apparell, and the Wise-woman.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Iack, thou art my Boy.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Mistris!

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Ile be a Mother to thee, no Mistris: come Lad, I must have thee sworne to the orders of my house, and the secrets thereof.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: As I am an honest Lad, I am yours to command. But Mistris, what meane all these womens pictures, hang'd here in your withdrawing roome?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Ile tell thee, Boy; marry thou must be secret. When any Citizens, or yong Gentlemen come hither, under a colour to know their Fortunes, they looke upon these pictures, and which of them they best like, she is ready with a wet finger: here they have all the furniture belonging to a privat-chamber, bedde, bed-fellow and all; but mum, thou knowest my meaning, Iacke.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: But I see comming and going, Maids, or such as goe for Maids, some of them, as if they were ready to lie downe, sometimes two or three delivered in one night; then suddenly leave their Brats behind them, and conveigh themselves into the Citie againe: what becomes of their Children?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Those be Kitchin-maids, and Chamber-maids, and sometimes good mens Daughters; who having catcht a clap, and growing neare their time, get leave to see their friends in the Countrey, for a weeke or so: then hither they come, and for a matter of money, here they are delivered. I have a Mid wife or two belonging to the house, and one Sir Boniface a Deacon, that makes a shift to christen the Infants: we have poore, honest, and secret Neighbours, that stand for common Gossips. But dost not thou know this?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Yes, now I doe: but what after becomes of the poore Infants?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Why, in the night we send them abroad, and lay one at this mans doore, and another at that, such as are able to keepe them; and what after becomes of them, we inquire not. And this is another string to my Bowe.

lg.l: Most strange, that womans brain should apprehend
Such law lesse, indirect, and horrid meanes
For covetous gaine! How many unknowne Trades
Women and men are free of, which they never
Had Charter for? but Mistris, are you so
Cunning as you make your selfe: you can
Neither write nor reade, what doe you with hose
Bookes you so often turne over?

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Why tell the leaves; for to be ignorant, and seeme ignorant, what greater folly?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Beleeve me, this is a cunning Woman; neither hath shee her name for nothing, who out of her ignorance, can foole so many that thinke themselves wise. But wherefore have you built this little Closet close to the doore, where sitting, you may heare every word spoken, by all such as aske for you.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: True, and therefore I built it: if any knock, you must to the doore and question them, to find what they come about, if to this purpose, or to that. Now they ignorantly telling thee their errand, which I sitting in my Closet, over heare, presently come forth, and tell them the cause of their comming, with every word that hath past betwixt you in private: which they admiring, and thinking it to be miraculous, by their report I become thus famous.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: This is no Trade, but a Mysterie; and were I a Wise-woman, as indeed I am but a foolish Boy, I need not live by your service. But Mistris, we lose our selves in this discourse, is not this the morning in which I should be married?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Now, how had I forgot my selfe? Mistris Luce promist to be with mee halfe an houre agoe, but mask't and disguis'd, and so shalt thou be too: here's a blacke Vaile to hide thy face against the rest come.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Sit tibi bona dies: salus & quies.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Into the withdrawing roome, Sir Boniface.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Without any compunction, I will make the Conjunction.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Now keepe thy countenance, Boy.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Feare not mee, I have as good a face in a Maske, as any Lady in the Land could wish to have: but to my heart, hee comes, or he comes not; now am I in a pittifull perplexity, untill I see the event of all.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: No more Iacke now, but Mistris Luce.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I warrant you Mistris: that it happens so luckily, that my name should be Luce too, to make the marriage more firme!
sp.stage: Enter Chartley disguis'd, and in a Visard.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: My honey sweet Hagge, where's Luce?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Here sweet heart, but disguis'd and vail'd, as you are visarded.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: But what's the reason wee are thus Hood-winkt?

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: No discovery of your selves for a million, there's Sir Boniface within, shall hee blab who you are? Besides, there's a yong Heire that hath stolne a Lords Daughter from the Court, and would not have their faces seene for a World: cannot you be content to fare well, and keepe your owne counsell, and see, yonder they come.
sp.stage: Enter at severall places, Boyster visarded, and Luce mask't.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Gramarcie my Sugar-candie sweet Trot.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Mum, no more words.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: If the great Heire and the yong Lady be so dainty of their Complexions, they shall see (my sweet Luce) wee can visard it with the best of them.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: That Gentleman, by the Wisewomans description, should be Master Chartley. (Meaning Boyster.)

lg.l: That gallant Wench, if my Grannam fable not,
Should be Luce: but what be those other?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
You wrong mee, but to aske, who but a yong
Heire, and a Lady of the Court: that's Luce, take her, and keepe your promise.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Pocas palabras.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: That's Chartley, take him Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: But who be they?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.

lg.l: A Lord and Lady shall Sir Boniface stay,
Rather then so, strive who should leade the way.

sp.stage: Exeunt Chartley with Iack, Boyster with Luce.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Now Iack my Boy, keepe thine owne counsell, and countenance, and I shall cry quittance with my yong Gallant. Well, by this time Sir Boniface is at his Booke. But because there is a mistake, knowne onely to my Boy and my selfe; the Marriage shall be no sooner ended, but Ile disturbe them by some sudden out-cry, and that too, before they have leasure to unmaske, and make knowne themselves one to another; for if the deceite were knowne, I should fall into the danger of that yong mad Rascall. And now this double apprehension of the Lord and the Lady shall fetch mee off from all; I know it is Sir Boniface his custome, to make short worke, and hath dispatcht by this: And now Wise-woman, try if thou canst bestir thy selfe like to a Mad-woman— shift for your selves, Warrants and Pursevants! Away, Warrants and Pursevants! shift for your selves.
sp.stage: Enter, as affrighted and amazed, Chartley, Boyster, Boniface, and others.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Ile take this way.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I this.

lg.l: Curro Curris Curcurri: My cheeks are all Murry,
And I am gone in an hurry.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O Heaven! what shall become of me?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I know what shall become of me already.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
O sweet Daughter, shift cloathes with this
Lady! Nay, as thou lov'st thy credit and mine, change Habits— So, if thou bee'st taken in her Garments, finding the mistake, will let thee passe; and should they meet her in thine, not knowing her, would no way question her: and this prove to both your securities and my safety.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: As fast as I can, good Mother: So Madam farewell.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: All happy joyes betide you.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Ha, ha, let me hold my sides, and laugh: Here were even a Plot to make a play on, but that Chartley is so fool'd by my Boy Iacke: Well, heele make a notable Wagge, Ile warrant him. All the Iest will bee, if Boyster should meete with him in Luce's habitt, which hee hath now on, hee would thinke himselfe meerely gull'd and cheated; and should Chartley meet with Luce as shee is now Roab'd, hee would bee confident hee had marryed her. Let mee see how many Trades have I to live by: First, I am a Wise-woman, and a Fortune-teller, and under that I deale in Physicke and Fore-speaking, in Palmistry, and recovering of things lost. Next, I undertake to cure Madd folkes. Then I keepe Gentlewomen Lodgers, to furnish such Chambers as I let out by the night: Then I am provided for bringing young Wenches to bed; and for a need, you see I can play the Match-maker. Shee that is but one, and professeth so many, may well bee tearmed a Wise-woman, if there bee any.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
Why, runne away, and leave my Wench behind? Ile backe: what have Warrants and Pursevants to doe with mee? with mee? why should I budge? why should I weare Maske or Visard? If Lords or Ladies offend, let Lords and Ladies answer; let mee better bethinke mee. Why should I play at Hob-man blinde? Hum; why marry in Tenebris, ha! is there no tricke in it? If my
Grannam should make mee a yonger Brother now, and instead of Luce, pop mee off with some broken commoditie, I were finely serv'd: most sure I am, to be in for better and worse, but with whom, Heaven and my Grannam knowes.
sp.stage: Enter halfe ready and maskt, 2. Luce.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I am stolne out of doores, to see if I can meet my Husband; with whom I purpose to make some sport, ere I suddenly disclose my selfe: what's hee?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Heyday, what have wee here, an Hoberdehoy? come hither you.

lg.l: 'Tis Mistris Luces Husband,
Ile not leave him thus.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Doe you not know mee?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: That Maske and Robe I know?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I hope so, or else I were in a woe case.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: That Maske, that Gowne I married.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Then you have no reason, but to injoy both them and me too, and so you are like; I should be loath to divorce Man and Wife.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I am fool'd, but what crackt ware are you, forsooth?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I belong to the old Gentlewoman of the house.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Ile set her house on fire: I am finely bobb'd.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: But I hope you will not bobb me.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: No I'se warrant thee: what art thou? Girle or Boy?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Both, and neither; I was a Ladd last night, but in the morning I was conjured into a Lasse: And being a Girle now, I shall be translated to a Boy anon. Here's all I can at this time say for my selfe: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
Yes, and be hang'd withall. O for some Gun
powder to blow up this Witch, this Shee-male, this damn'd Sorceresse! O I could teare her to fitters with my teeth! Yet I must be patient, and put up all, lest I bee made a jeere to such as know mee: fool'd by a Boy! Goe too, of all the rest, the Girle Luce must not know it.
sp.stage: Enter Chartley and his man, meeting Luce.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: So, now am I the same man I was yesterday; who can say I was disguis'd? or who can distinguish my condition now? or reade in my face, whether I be a married man, or a Batchelor?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Sweet Husband, is it you?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: The newes?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Never so frighted in my dayes.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: What's become of the Lord and the Lady?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: The Lord fled after you, the Lady staid; who maskt, and halfe unready, ran fast after her poore affrighted Husband: now all's quiet.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: This storme is then well past, and now conveigh your selfe home as privately as you can: and see you make this knowne to none but your Father.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I am your Wife and Servant.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: This name of Luce hath beene ominous to mee; one Luce I should have married in the Countrey, and just the night before, a toy tooke me in the head, and mounting my Horse, I left Capons, Ducks, Geese, Poultry, Wild-fowle, Father, and Bride and all, and posted up to London, where I have ever since continued Batchelor, till now. And now—

div.stage: Enter Gratiana in haste, a Serving-man before her, and Taber after her.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Nay on, I Prethee fellow on, my Father will wonder where I have beene visiting. Now, what had I forgot? Taber, there's money, goe to the Gold-smiths, bid him send mee my Fanne; and make a quicke returne: on, fellow on.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Her Fanne at the Gold-smiths! now had I forgot to aske her his name, or his signe: but I will after to know.

lg.l: Sirrah, goe call mee backe that Serving-man,
And aske him what's the Gentle-womans name.

sp.speaker: Servingman.
sp.p: I shall; ho, you: Friend, you.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Who's that calls?

sp.speaker: Servingman.
sp.p: 'Twas I.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Your businesse? you should be one, though not of my cognisance, yet of my condition: a Serving-creature, as I take it: pray what's your will with mee?

sp.speaker: Servingman.
sp.p: Pray Sir, what might I call that Gentlewoman, on whom you were attendant?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: You may call her what you please, but if you call her otherwise then in the way of honestie, you may perchance heare on't.

sp.speaker: Servingman.
sp.p: Nay, be not offended: I say, what doe you call her?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Why Sir, I call her as it shall best please mee, sometimes yong Lady, sometimes yong Mistris; and what hath any man to doe with that?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Are you so captious, sirrah, what's her name? Speake, and be briefe.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Ey marry Sir, you speake to purpose, and I can resolve you: her name is Gratiana. But all this while I have forgot my Mistris Fanne.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Gratiana! oft have I heard of her, but saw her
not till now: 'tis a prettie wench, a very prettie wench, nay, a very, very, very prettie wench. But what a Rogue am I, of a married man? nay, that have not beene married this six houres, and to have my shittle-wits runne a Wooll-gathering already? What would poore Luce say if shee should heare of this? I may very well call her poore Luce, for I cannot presume of five pounds to her portion: what a Coxcombe was I, being a Gentleman, and well deriv'd, to match into so beggarly a kindred? What needed I to have grafted in the stocke of such a Choake Peare, and such a goodly Popering as this to escape mee? Escape mee (said I?) if shee doe, shee shall doe it narrowly: but I am married already, and therefore it is not possible, unlesse I should make away my wife, to compasse her. Married! why who knowes it? Ile out-face tho Priest, and then there is none but shee and her Father, and their evidence is not good in Law: and if they put mee in suite, the best is, they are poore, and cannot follow it. I marry Sir, a man may have some credit by such a Wife as this; I could like this marriage well, if a man might change away his Wife, still as hee is a weary of her, and cope her away like a bad commoditie: if every new Moone a man might have a new Wife, that's every yeare a dozen. But this, Till Death us depart, is tedious: I will goe a wooing to her, I will; but how shall I doe for jewels and tokens? Luce hath mine in her custodie, money and all; tush, Ile juggle them from her well enough: see, here shee comes.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Here is my Husband, I pray move him in it.

lg.l: It toucheth both our reputations nearly;
For by his oft repaire, now whilst the Marriage
Is kept from publike knowledge, your good name
May be by Neighbours hardly censur'd of.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Th'art sad, Th'art sad Luce what, melancholly already, ere thou hast had good cause to be merry, and knowst what sport was.

lg.l: I have great reason, when my name is toss'd
In every Gossips mouth, and made a by-word
Vnto such people as it least concernes.
Nay, in my hearing, as they passe along,
Some have not spar'd to brand my modestie,
Saying, There sits shee whom yong Chartley keepes.
There hath hee entred late, betimes gone forth.
Where I with pride was wont to sit before,
I'm now with shame sent blushing from the doore.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Alas poore foole, I am sorry for thee, but yet cannot helpe thee, as I am a Gentleman. Why say Luce, thou losest now forty shillings worth of Credit, stay but a time, and it shall bring thee in a thousand pounds worth of commoditie.

lg.l: Son, Son, had I esteem'd my profit more
Then I have done my credit, I had now
Beene many thousands richer: but you see,
Truth and good dealing beare an humble saile;
That little I injoy, it is with quiet,
Got with good conscience, kept with good report:
And that I still shall labour to preserve.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: But doe you heare mee?

lg.l: Nothing Ile heare, that tends unto the ruine
Of mine, or of my Daughters honestie.
Shall I be held a Broker to lewd Lust,
Now in my waine of yeares?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Will you but heare mee?

lg.l: Not in this case. I that have liv'd thus long,
Reported well, esteem'd a welcome Guest
At every burthen'd Table, there respected;
Now to be held a Pander to my Daughter?
That I should live to this!

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: But harke you Father?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: A Bawd to mine owne child!

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Father?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: To my sweet Luce!

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Father?

lg.l: Deale with me like a Son, then call me Father;
I that have had the tongues of every man
Ready to crowne my Reputation:
The hands of all my Neighbours to subscribe
To my good like; and such as could not write,
Ready with Palsie and unlettered fingers,
To set their scribbling markes.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Why Father in Law?

lg.l: Thou hadst a Mother Luce; 'tis woe with me
To say thou hadst, but hast not; a kind Wife,
And a good Nurse she was: she, had she liv'd
To heare my name thus canvast, and thus toss'd,
Seven yeares before she dy'd, I had beene a Widower
Seven yeares before I was: Heaven rest her soule,
Shee is in Heaven I hope.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Why so now, these be good words, I knew these stormes would have a showre, and then they would cease. Now if your anger be over, heare me.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Well, say on Son.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Stay but a Moneth, 'tis but foure Weekes; nay, 'tis February, the shortest Moneth of the yeare, and in that time I shall be at full age; and the Land being intail'd, my Father can dis-inherit mee of nothing. Is your spleene downe now Have I satisfied you? Well, I see you chollericke hasty men, are the kindest when all is done. Here's such wetting of Hand-kerchers, hee weepes to thinke of his Wife, shee weepes to see her Father cry! Peace foole, wee shall else have thee claime kindred of the Woman kill'd with kindnesse.

lg.l: Well Son, my anger's past; yet I must tell you,
It grieves mee that you should thus slight it off,
Concerning us, no such a deere degree.
In private be it spoke, my Daughter tels me,
Shee's both a Wife and Maid.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: That may be help't.

Now Luce, your Fathers pacifi'd, will you be pleas'd? I would indure a Quarters punishment for thee, and wilt not thou suffer a poore Moneths penance for mee? 'Tis but eight and twenty dayes, Wench; thou shalt fare well all the time, drinke well, eate well, lie well: come, one word of comfort at the later end of the day.

lg.l: Yours is my fame, mine honour, and my heart
Link't to your pleasure, and shall never part.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Gramercie Wench, thou shalt weare this chaine no longer for that word, Ile multiply the linkes in such order, that it shall have light to shine about thy necke, oftener then it doth: this jewell, a plaine Bristowe stone, a counterfeit. How base was I, that comming to thee in the way of Marriage, courted thee with counterfeit stones? Thou shalt weare right, or none: thou hast no money about thee, Luce?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I have the hundred pounds that you gave me to lay up last.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Fetch it; let mee see, how much branch'd Sattin goes to a Petticoat? and how much wrought Velvet to a Gowne? then for a Bever for the Citie, and a Blackbagge for the Country: Ile promise her nothing, but if any such trifles bee brought home, let her not thanke mee for them.
Gramercie Luce, Nay, goe in, Gravitie and Modestie, ten to one but you shall heare of mee, e're you see mee againe.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p:
I know you kinde, impute my hastie Language
unto my rage, not mee.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Why, doe not I know you, and doe not I know her? I doubt you'l wish shortly that I had never knowne either of you: now, what sayst thou, my sweet Luce?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: My words are yours. so is my life: I am now part of your selfe, so made by Nuptiall vowes.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: What a Pagan am I, to practise such villany against this honest Christian! If Gratiana did come into my thoughts, I should fall into a vaine 'to pittie her: but now that I talk of her, I have a tongue to wooe her, Tokens to win her; and that done, if I doe not find a tricke, both to weare her, and wearie her, it may prove a piece of a Wonder. Thou seest, Luce, I have some store of Crownes about me, there are brave things to be bought in the Citie; Cheapside, and the Exchange, afford varietie and raritie. This is all I will say now, but thou mayest heare more of mee hereafter.

lg.l: Heaven speed you where you goe Sir; shall we in?
Though not from scandall, wee live free from Sin.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Ile in before.

lg.l: I am still in love with Luce, and I would know
An answer more directly: fie, fie, this Love
Hangs on me like an Ague, makes me turne foole,
Coxcombe and Asse: why should I love her, why?
A Rattle-Baby, Puppit, a slight toy,
And now I could goe to buffets with my selfe,
And cuffe this Love away: but see, that's Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I cannot shun him, but Ile shake him off.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Morrow.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: As much to you.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I'le use few words, Canst love me?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Deed Sir no.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Why the farewell, the way I came, Ile goe.

lg.l: This is no tedious Courtship, hee's soone answer'd,
So should all Sutors else bee, were they wise;
For being repulst, they doe but waste their dayes
In thanklesse suites, and superficiall praise.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Sweare that thou wilt not love me.

lg.l: Not Sir, for any hate I ever bare you,
Or any foolish pride, or vaine conceite:
Or that your feature doth not please mine eye,
Or that you are not a brave Gentleman:
But for concealed reasons I am forc'd
To give you this cold answer; and to sweare
I must not, then with patience pray forbeare.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Even farewell then.

lg.l: The like to you, and save your hopes in me.
Heaven grant you your best wishes; all this strife
Will end it selfe, when I am knowne a Wife.

div.head: Actus 4us. Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Sir Harry, M. Harringsfield Gratiana with others.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I am satisfied good M. Harringsfield touching your friend, and since I see you haue left his dangerous company, I limit you to bee a welcome guest vnto my Table.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: You haue bin alwayes noble.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Taber: the newes with thee?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: May it please the right worshipfull to vnderstand that there are some at the Gate who dance a turne or two without, and desire to bee admitted to speake with you within.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: The Scholler is it not.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Nay sir, there are two Schollers, and they are spowting Latin one against the other; And in my simple Iudgement the stranger is the better Scholler, and is somewhat too hard for sir Boniface: For he speakes lowder, and that you know is ever the signe of the most learning, and hee also hath a great desire to serue your Worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Two schollers; My house hath not place for two, thus it shall bee. Taber admit them both, wee though vnlearned will heare them two dispute, and hee that of the two seemes the best read, shall bee receiued, the other quite casheired.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: In that you showe but Iustice, in all persons merit should bee regarded.
sp.stage: Enter Taber vshering sir Boniface and Sencer, disguised like a pedant.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Venerabilis magistri: Absint vobis capistri.

lg.l: Et tu domini calve, iterum atque, iterum salve,
Amo amas amavi, sweete Lady Heauen saue yee.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: This approues him to be excellent, but I thank my breeding I vnderstand not a word, you tong-men you whose wealth lyes in your braines; Not in your budgets heere mee: Be it knowne, my house affords roome for one Schoole-master but not for more. And I am thus resolved, take you that side gentle sir Boniface, and sir possesse you that.
Hee of you two in arguing prooues the best. To him will I subscribe are you agreed.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Nec animo, nec corde, nec vtroque.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: No more of that nec corde, noble Knight, he wishes you nec corde, thinke of that.

lg.l: A Cord about my necke, sir Boniface.
Speake doe you use mee well.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Domine currogas:

lg.l: Is this to bee indured, to call a Knight.
Cur, Rogue and Asse.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I find my selfe abus'd.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: Yet patience good syr Harry, and heare more pray sir Boniface: of what Vniversitie? Were you of.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: I was student in Brazen nose.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: A man might guesse so much by your pimples, and of what place were you:

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Petrus dormit securus; I was Sir of Peeter house Sir Boniface. Natus eram, in Woxford, and I proceeded in Oxford.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Est mihi bene nostrum, thou wouldest say, in Gotam; For my part sir Harry, I can reade Seruice and Marry, Que genus et flexum, though I goe in genes Fustion, scalpellum et charta I was not brought vp at Plowe & cart, I can teach Qui mihi, and neyther laugh nor tee-hee, sed as in presente, if your worship at this present, Iste, Ista Istud, will doe mee any good, to giue mee legem pone in
Gold or in monie. Piper atque papauer, I'le deserue it with my labour.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: But when goe you to dispute.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Nomnativo hic prediculus, his words are most ridiculous: But tu thou, qui the which, deridest those that bee rich, consterue hanc sententiam, construe mee this sentence. Est modus in rebus sunt certi denique fines:

lg.l: Est modus in rebus: There is mud in the rivers.
Sunt certi denique fines, and certaine little Fishes.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I warrant you he hath his answer ready.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Dij boni boni.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: Heele giue you more bones then those to know on Sir Boniface.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Kartere Moosotropos Poluphiltate phile poetatis Tes Logikes retoon, onch elashiste sophoon.

That is as much as to say, in our materna lingua I will make you sir Boniface, confesse your selfe an Asse in English, speake open and broad words, for want of Latin, and Denique instruct mee to resolue such questions as I shall aske you in our moderne tongue.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Confesse him an Asse, speake obsceane words after intreate thee to resolve thy questions. Doe that, possese the place.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Di do and dum: No more words but mum:

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Noble sir Harry; Nunquam sic possit?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sir Boniface is sicke already and calls for a possit, no marvell, being so threatned.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: You Boniface, decline mee I am a no after the first coniugation, amo amavi, vocito vocitavi. Titubo titubavi?

lg.l: I am not the preceptor to a pupill.
But can decline it, marke sir Timothy:
I am a no,

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Bene bene.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: I am an as?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Most treue most treue, vos estis, ut egojum testes,
that what he confest is, as true as the pestis.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: This Scholler workes by magick hee hath made him confesse himselfe an Asse.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Per has meas manus vir, tues insanus,

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Ile make him fret worse yet; Sir Bouiface: quid est grammatica.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Grammatica est ars,

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Fye, fye, no more of these words good sir Boniface.

lg.l: Attend againe, proceed mee with this verse
of reverent Cato: Si deus est animus-

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Nobis ut carmina dicunt.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Di quoth ha, out on him for a beastly man.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I would not haue him teach my children so for more then I am worth.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: O! but reverend syr Harry you must subaudi.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Ile never bee so baudy whilest I liue, nor any of mine I hope.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: O! Propria quae maribus:

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Ey Boniface, it is those maribones, that makes you talke so broadly?

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Venerabilis vir homo ille est ebrius.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: What doth hee meane by that.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: He saith, I can speake Hebrewe

lg.l: I Beleeu't:
But if syr Boniface still con these lessons,
He'l, speake the French tongue perfit.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Now to the last, ile taske syr Boniface, but with an easie question. Tell mee syr: Whats Latin for this Earth?

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Facile and easy more fit for the pupill then the preceptor: whats Latin for this Earth? Tellus.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Tell you; no syr, it belongs to you to tell mee.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: I say Tellus is Latin for the Earth.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: And I say, I will not tell you what is Latin for the Earth; vnlesse you yeild mee victor:

lg.l: You haue no reason: good syr Timothy,
The place is yours.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: Hee hath deserv'd it well.

lg.l: But ile deserue it better, why this fellow
is Franticke, you shall heere mee make him speake
Idely and without sence. I'le make him say,
His Nose was Husband to a Queene,

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Sir Timothy not possible.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Hee will not speake it for shame.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: That you shall heere; Magister Boniface.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Quid ais domine Timothy.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Who was Pasiphas husband Queene of Creete.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Who knowes not that, why Minos was her Husband.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: That his nose was; did I not tell you so.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: I say that Minos was:

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: That his Nose was ha has.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Ile not beleeue it.

lg.l: there are a brace of Angels.
You are not for my turne sir Timothy.
You are the man shall reade vnto my daughter
The Latin tongue, in which I am ignorant:
Confesse your selfe an Asse; speake bawdy words;
And after to talke idely. Hence away:
You shall haue my good word, but not my pay?
Opus est vsus; sir Timothy you abuse us.
Is weare by a nowne, had I thy hose downe,
Qui que quod, I would so smoake thee with the rod:
Ille Illa Illud, vntill I fetch blood.
But Nobiles valete, remaine in quiete.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.

lg.l: Sir Timothy, there is some Gold in earnest,
I like you well take into your tuition,

sp.p: My daughter Gratiana; the newes Taber.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Of another gallant noble sir that pretends to haue businesse, both with you and my mistresse,

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Admit him.

div.stage: Enter Chartly very gallant, in his hand a Lady.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Lusty Iuventus; will it please you to draw neere.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Noble Knight, whil'st you peruse that sweete Lady, tell mee how you like this:

lg.l: You presse so suddainly vpon mee syr
I know not what to answer.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Mad Chartly; what makes desperation heere.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: To the word wooer let mee add the name speeder my father hath written to your father, and the cause of his writing at this present, is to let you vnderstand, that hee feares you haue liu'd a maide too long: and therefore to prevent all diseases incident to the same; as the greene sicknesse and others. Hee sent mee like a skilfull Physitian, to take order with you against all such maladies. If you will not credit mee, list but how fervently my father writes in my behalfe.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Hee is my onely sonne, and shee I take as your onely daughter, what should hinder then,
To make a match betweene them, (well tis well tis good I like it) I will make her Ioynter three hundred pounds a yeare.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: How say you by that sweete Lady three hundred pounds a yeare and a proper man to boote.

lg.l: All's good, I like it, welcome M. Chartly.
Thou Gratiana art no child of mine
Vnlesse thou bidst him welcome. This I presume
To bee your fathers hand.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: But Ile bee sworne he never writ it.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: And this his seale at Armes.

lg.l: Or else I vnderstand it very poorely, but Lady
In earnest of further acquaintance, receiue this Chayne,
These Iewels, hand and heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Refase no Chaine nor Iewels, heart nor hand, but in exchange of these bestowe thy selfe thine owne deere selfe vpon him.

sp.speaker: Gratia.
sp.p: My selfe on him, whom I tell now I neere saw? Well since I must, your will's to mee a law.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Nay then tis time to speake, shall I stand heere waiting like a Coxcombe, and see her giuen away before my face? stay your hand syr Harry; and let mee claime my promise.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: My promise ile performe syr Timothy, you shall haue all your wages duly paid.

lg.l: I claime faire Gratiana by your promise.
No more syr Timothy, but Sencer now,
You promis'd mee when you receiued my service,
And with your liberall hand did wage my stay:
To endowe mee freely with your daughters Love,
That promise now I claime.
Meere cosnidge, knavery,
I tide my selfe to no conditions.
In which such guile is practised, come sonne Chartly,
To cut of all disasters incident.
To these proceedings wee will sollemnise
These Nuptiall rites with all speede possible.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Farewell good syr Timothy; farewell learn'd syr Timothy.

lg.l: Why: and farewell learned syr Timothy.
For now syr Timothy and I are two:
Boast on, bragge on, exalt exalt thy selfe,
Swim in a Sea of pleasure and content
Whilst my Barke suffers wrack ile bee revenged,
Chartly; ile cry vindicta for this Horne,
Next time thou gorest, it must bee with thy horne,
I am mad, and know not at what.
I could swagger but know not with whom,
I am at oddes with my selfe; and know not why:
I shall bee pacified, and cannot tell when,
I would faine haue a wife but cannot tell where,
I would fasten on Luce but cannot tell how.
How; where; when; why; whom; what.
Feeding sure makes mee leane, and fasting fat.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Not all this while once see mee.

sp.speaker: Ioseph.
sp.p: His occasions, perhaps inforce his absence.

lg.l: His occasions:
Vnlesse hee find occasion of new Love.
What could inforce such absence from his spouse:
Am I growne fowle and blacke, since my espousals.
It should not seeme so; For the shop is daily,
Custom'd with store of Chap-men, such as come
To cheapen Love. O no, I am my selfe?
But Chartly hee is changed.

sp.speaker: Ioseph.
sp.p: You know that Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Escape him if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Hee cannot, I arrest you;

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: At whose suite.

lg.l: Not at mine owne, thats dasht, I loue thee not.
Thou art a Spaniard, Gipsee, a meere Blackamore:
Againe, I say I loue thee not.
A Blackemore, a Gipsy?
Sure I am chang'd indeed, and that's the cause
My Husband left mee so, this Gentleman
Once tearmd mee beautifull, how looke I Ioseph.

sp.speaker: Ioseph.
sp.p: As well as ere you did, fat, fresh, and fayre.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: You lye boy, pocket that, and now be gon.

sp.speaker: Ioseph.
sp.p: And what shall then become of my Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Ile waite vpon your Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I know you will not waite on such a Gipsie.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Yes Luce on such a Gipsie: Boy, abi abi.

sp.speaker: Ioseph.
sp.p: Abide fir, you neede not feare that I haue no purpose to leaue her.

lg.l: Now you are going to the wedding-house.
You are bid to be a Bride maid, are you not.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: What wedding sir, or whose?

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Why Chartleyes; Luce hath hee bin thy friend so long, and would not bid thee to write on his Bride. Why lookst thou red and pale, and both, and neither.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: To Mr. Chartleyes Bridals, why, to whom, Should hee be married.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: To Grace of Gratious street.

lg.l: To Gratiana?
Beshrow you sir you doe not use mee well,
To buze into mine eares these strange vntruths:
I tell you sir, 'tis as impossible
That they two should match: as Earth and Heauen to meet.

sp.speaker: Boyster.

lg.l: You'l not beleeue it, pray then harke within,
The Nuptiall musicke ecchoing to their ioyes.
But you giue credit to no certaintyes:
I told you but a tale, a lye, a fable?
A monstrous, a notorious idle untruth,
That you were blacke, and that I lou'd you not.
And you could credit that.

sp.stage: Enter sir Harry and Harings-field, Chartly leading Gratiana by the Arme, Taber and attendants.

lg.l: Who's tell-troth now.
Know you that man, or know you that fine Virgin:
Whom by the arme hee leades.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I'le not indure't: Heauen giue you joy sir:

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: I thanke you: Luce?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Looke to the Maid shee faints.

lg.l: Grace, come not neere her Grace.
