Father keepe off, on Gentlemen apace.
Shees troubled with the falling sicknesse, for
Oft hath shee fallen before mee.
Nay if it bee no otherwise, on gentlemen.
Let those with her striue to recouer her.
Keepe off, the disease is infectious:

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: If it were in a man, it were nothing, but the falling sicknesse in a woman is dangerous.
My tother father in Lawe, now shall I bee vtterly sham'd, If hee assure to know mee, I'le out face him.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Sonne your well met.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: How fellow.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: I cry you mercy sir.

sp.speaker: Chart
sp.p: No harme done friend, no harme done.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: If hee? hee could not but haue known mee there, Yet he was wondrous like him.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: How cheare you Luce, whence grew this passion.

lg.l: Pardon mee sir, I doe not know my selfe:
I am apt to swound, and now the fit is past mee.
I thanke you for your helpe; is master Chartly
Vanisht so soone:

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Yes: and to supply his place, see where thy father comes.

lg.l: Hee hath not such a suit, besides this gallant
Led by the arme a Bride, a lusty Bride?
How much might I haue wrong'd the Gentleman.
By craving his acquaintance, this it is,
To haue dimme Eyes. Why lookes my daughter sad.
I cry you mercy. Sir I saw not you.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I would I had not seene you at this time neither, farewell.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: If hee be gone? then call mee vent my griefe, Father I am vndone,

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Forbid it Heauen.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Disgrac't, despis'd, discarded, and cast off.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: How, mine owne child:

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: My Husband, O my husband?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: What of him.

lg.l: Shall I the shower of all my griefe at once
Power out before you: Chartly, once my husband
Hath left mee to my shame. Him and his Bride,
I met within few minutes.
Sure t'was they.
I met them two, t'was hee; base villaine Iewe.
I'le to the Wedding boord, and tell him so:
Ile doo't as I am a man?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Bee not so rash.

lg.l: Ile liue and dye vpon him;
Hee's a base fellow, so I'le prooue him too.
Ioseph my Sword.
This rashnesse will vndoe us.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Ile haue my Sword.

lg.l: It hath bin twice in France, and once in Spaine,
With Iohn a Gaunt, when I was young like him
I had my wards, and foynes, and quarter-blowes:
And knew the way into St. Georges fields.
Twice in a morning, Tuttle, Finsbury?
I knew them all, ile too him, wher's my sword,
Or leaue this spleene, or you will ouerthrow
Our fortunes quite, let us consult together,
What wee were best to doe.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: I'le make him play at Leap-frog, well I heare thee

lg.l: I cannot proue our marriage, it was secret,
And hee may find some cavell in the Law.
I'le too him with no Law, but Staffood Lawe.
I'le ferret the false boy, nay on good Luce.
Part of your spleene, if you would change to counsel,
Wee might revenge us better.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Well I heare thee.

lg.l: To claime a publicke marriage at his hands:
Wee want sufficient proofe, and then the world
Will but deride our folly, and so adde
Dubble disgrace vnto my former wrong.
To Law with him hee hath a greater purse,
And nobler friends, how then to make it knowne?
Is this his damask'd kirtle frendge with Gold,
His blacke bagge, and his Beaner, tis well yet
I haue a Sword:
And I haue a project in my Braine begot,
To make his owne mouth witnes to the World
My innocence, and his incontinence?
Leaue it to mee, ile cleare my selfe from blame,
Though I the wrong, yet hee shall reape the shame.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Now or never, looke about thee Sencer, tomorrow is the Marriage day which to preuent, lyes not within the compasse of my apprehension, therefore I haue thus disguised my selfe, to goe to the, Looming womans, the Fortune tellers. The any thing, the nothing, this over against mother Red-caps is her house, ile knocke.
sp.stage: Enter 2. Luce in her boyes shape.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Whos's there? What would you haue.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: I would speake with the wise gentlewoman of the house.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: O belike you haue lost somewhat.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: You are in the wrong sweete youth.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I am somewhat thicke of hearing, pray speak out.

lg.l: I say I haue not lost any thing, but wit and time,
And neither of those she can helpe mee too:

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Then you belike are crost in Loue, and come to know what successe you shall haue.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Thou hast hit it sweete ladde; thou hast hit it.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: What is it, you say sir:

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Thou hast hit it?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I pray come in, ile bring you to my Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: This is the house, knock Ioseph, my businesse craues dispatch.

sp.speaker: Ioseph.
sp.p: Now am I as angry, as thou art timerous, and now to vent the next thing I meete, O tis the doore.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Who's there, what are you.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: A maid and a wife.

lg.l: And that would grieue any wench to bee so,
I know that by my selfe, not Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Boy, where's your Mistresse.

lg.l: In some private talke with a Gentleman?
Ile fetch her to you presently.
If shee and you see mee not, I am but dead,
I shall be made, a by-word to the World:
The scorne of women; and my Fathers shame:

sp.speaker: Wisewoman.
sp.p: You tell mee your name is Sencer, I knew it before, and that Chartly is to bee married, I could haue told it you.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Married to morrow, O mee!

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Ey but you tell mee, that Chartly before to morrow shall bee disappointed of his, make that good, Thou shalt haue twenty Angels.

sp.speaker: Wisewoman.
sp.p: Ile doo't, stand aside, ile haue but a word or two with this Gentlewoman; and I am for you presently.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O! Mother, mother.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
My husband marry another wife tomorrow? O changeable destinie, no sooner married to him, but instantly to loose him. Nor death it grieues mee so much that I am a wife, but that I am a maid too, to carry one of them
well is as much as any is bound to doe, but to be tide to both, is more then flesh and blood can indure.

sp.speaker: Wisewoman.
sp.p: Well trust to mee, and I will sell all things streight.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Wher's this Witch, this hagge, this beldan, this wisard, and haue I found thee, thus then will I teare, mumble and maule thee.

sp.speaker: Wisewoman.
sp.p: Helpe, helpe, and if you be a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Forbeare this rudenesse, hee that touches her, Drawes against mee.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Against you sir, apply thou, that shall be tride.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Helpe, helpe, part them helpe.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: With patience heare her speake.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Now Trot, now Granam, what canst thou say for thy selfe: what Luce heare be patient and put vp them, shee must not see the end.

lg.l: Than trince of all sides, if wee come for counsell,
Let us with patience heare it:

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Then first to mee.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: You would preuent young Chartlyes marriage, you shall: harke in your eare.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: It pleaseth mee.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: You-forestall Gratianes wedding, 'tis but thus.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Ile doo't,

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: You would inioy Luce as your wife, and lye with her to morrow night. Harke in your care.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Fiat.

lg.l: Away, you shall injoy him, you are married,
Luce away, you shall see Chartly discarded from Gratiana,
Sencer bee gon, and if I fayle in any of these or the rest,
I lay my selfe open to all your displeasures.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Farewell till soone:

sp.speaker: Wisewoman.
sp.p: You know your meeting place.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Wee doe?

sp.speaker: Wisewoman.
sp.p: You shall report mee wiser and cunning too.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.

lg.l: Ile adde one night more to the time, I haue said.
I haue not many I hope to liue a maid.

sp.stage: Enter Taber and Sir Boniface with a Trencher, with broken meate and a Napkin.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Fye, fye, what a time of trouble is this to morrow to morrow is my mistresse to be married, and wee seruingmen are so pusled.

lg.l: The dinner's halfe done, and before I say
Grace, and bid the old Knight and his guest proface.
A medicine from your trencher, good M. Taber.
As good a man as ere was sir Saber:
Well thinke it no shame, men of learning and wit, say study gets a stomacke, friend Taber a bit.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Lick cleane good sir Boniface, and saue the scraper a labour.

lg.l: But soft let mee ponder:
Know you him that comes yonder?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Most heartily welcome, would you speake with any heere.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Pray is the yong gentleman of the house at leisure.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Meane you the Bridegroome M. Chartly.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: I haue a Letter for him. You seeme to be a gentleman your selfe, acquaint him with my attendance, and I shall rest yours in all good offices.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Sir Boniface, pray keepe the gentleman company I will first acquaint your lippes with the vertue of the Seller.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Adesdem come neere, and tast of your beere. Welcome, sine dole, for puntis te vole,

sp.speaker: Sencer.

lg.l: When I tast of your liqour.
Gramercy master Vicar.

sp.stage: Enter Taber with a bowle of Beere and a Napkine.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Most heartily welcome: your curtesie I beseech you, ply it off I intreate you, pray sir Boniface keepe the Gentleman company; till I acquaint my yong master with his businesse.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Taber, I shall besolas manus.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: A vostre seruitor.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: Hee what art thou,

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: A hanger on, if it please you:

sp.speaker: Harring.

lg.l: And I a shaker off, ile not beare your gallowes,
You shall not hang on mee.

sp.stage: Enter Chartly with his Napkin as from Dinner.
sp.p: O. Mr Bridegroome.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Gentlemen, the Ladies call vpon you to dance, they will be out of measure displeased, if dinner beeing done, you bee not ready to leade them a measure:

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: Indeede women love not to bee scanted of their measure.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Fie sir Boniface: haue you forgot your selfe, Whilst you are in the Hall, there's never a whetstone for their wits in the Parler?

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: I will enter and set an edge vpon their Ingenies.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: To mee sir, from whom? a letter to her most deere, most louing, most kind friend Mr. Chartly these bee deliuered: sure from some wench or other I long to know the contents.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Now to cry quittance with you for my farewell learn'd sir Timothy.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Good newes, as I liue, there's for thy paines my good sir Pandarus: Hadst thou brought mee word my father had turnd vp his heeles. Thou couldst scarcely haue pleased mee better: (Hee reades) though I disclaime the name of wife, of which I account my selfe altogether vnworthy, yet let mee claime some small interest in your loue, this night I lye at the house where wee were married, (the Wisewomans I meane) where my maiden-head is to bee rifled, bid fayre for it, and inioy it, see mee this night or never, so may you marrying Gratiana, and louing mee, haue a sweete wife and a true friend: This night or never, your quondam wife: Hereafter your poore sweet-heart no other: Luce. So when I am tyr'd with Gratiana, that is when I am past grace. With her I can make my rendevowz, ile not slip this occasion, nor sleepe till I see her, thou art an honest ladde, and maist prooue a good Pimpe in time. Canst thou advise mee what colour, I may haue to compasse this commodity.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Sir, shee this night expects you, and prepares a costly banquet for you.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Ile goe, although the Devill and mischance looke bigge,

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Feyne some newes that such a peece of Land is falne to you, and you must instantly ride to take possession of it, or which is more probable, cannot you perswade them you haue receiu'd a letter that your Father lyes a dying.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: You rogue, I would hee did but the name of that newes is cal'd, too good to be true.

sp.speaker: Sencer
sp.p: And that if ever you will see him aliue, you must ride post into the Country.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Enough: if ever I prooue Knight errant thou shalt bee mine owne proper squire, for this thou hast fitted mee with a plot, doe but waite heere note how I will manage it,
Tabor my horse, for I must ride to night:

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: To night sir.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: So tell my Bride and Father, I haue newes that quite confounds my sences.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Harry, Gratiana and Harringsfield.

lg.l: How ride to night, the marriage day to morrow
And all things well provided for the feast.
O tell mee sweete, why doe you looke so pale.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: My Father, O my Father:

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: What of him.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: What of your father, Sonne?

lg.l: If ever I will heere his aged tongue.
Preach to mee counsell, or his palsy hand,
Stroake my wild head, and blesse mee, or his eyes:
Drop teare by teare which they haue often done,
At my misgovern'd rioting youth.
What should I more, if ever I would see;
The good old man aliue. Oh, Oh?

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Goe thy wayes for thou shalt ha't.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: But doe you meane to ride.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Ey Grace, all this night.

lg.l: Not all the night without alighting sure:
You'l finde more in't then to get vp and ride,
The Gentlemans riding, bootes and spurres.
Why Taber?
Nay Grace, now's no time.
To stand on scrupulous parting. Knewest thou my businesse.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: As shee shall knowe it:

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: And how I meane this night to toyle my selfe.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Marry hang you brock.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Thou would be moane my travell.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: I know t'would grieue her:

lg.l: You father, Grace, good Mr Harringsfield.
You sir, and all pray for mee Gentlemen, that in this darke
nights journey I may finde smooth way, sweete speed and
all things to my minde.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Wee'l see my sonne take horse.

lg.l: But I will stay.
I want the heart to see him post away?

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Saue you gentlewoman, I haue a message to deliver to one Mistress Gratiana, this should bee the Knights house her father.

lg.l: It is: The message that you haue to her.
You may acquaint mee with, for I am one
That knowes the inside of her thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Are you the Lady,

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: Sir I am the poore gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: There is a conning woman dwells not farre.
At Hogsden Lady, famous for her skill.
Besides some private talke that much concernes your fortunes in your love. Shee hath to shewe you this night if it shall please you walke so farre as to her house, an admirable suite.

lg.l: Of costly needle worke, which if you please.
You may by vnder-rate for halfe the valew
It cost the making, about sixe a clocke.
You may haue view thereof, but otherwise.
A Lady that hath crau'd the sight thereof:
Must haue the first refusall.
Ile not fayle her.
My husband beeing this day rid from home.
My leasure fitly serues mee, thanke you Mistresse?

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: At sixe à clocke.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: I will not fayle the houre.

lg.l: Now to sir Harry, his is the next place.
To meete at Hogsden his fayre daughter Grace.

div.head: Actus 5us. Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter old M. Chartly as new come out of the Country To inquire after his Sonne, and three or foure serving men with blew Coates to attend him.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Good heauen; This London is a stranger growne, and out of my acquaintance, this seauen yeares I haue not seene Pauls steeple, or Cheape, crosse.

sp.speaker: Gyles.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Hast thou not made inquiry for my Sonne.

lg.l: Yes sir, I haue askt about euery where for him,
But cannot heare of him.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Disperse your selues, inquire about the Tavernes, Ordinaryes, Bowle-allyes, Tenis courts, Gaming-houses. For there (I feare) hee will be found.

sp.speaker: Gyles.
sp.p: But where shall wee heare of your worship againe.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: At Grace Church by the Conduit, neere Sir Harry, but stay, leaue off a while your bootlesse search, had e're man such a wild braine to his sorrow, of such small hope, who when hee should haue married a fayre, a modest, and a vertuous maide, rich and revenewed well, and even the night before the marriage day, tooke horse, road thence whether Heaven knowes, since the distracted virgin hath left her Fathers house, but neather feumd, yet in their search wee haue measured out much Ground.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Your worship will bee there.

lg.l: Yes, not to fayle.
At halfe an houre past sixe, or before seaven.
You shall not finde us at sixe and at seaven, ile
Warrant you: good health to your worship.
Farewell good fellow,
At the Wisewomans house I know it well:
Perhaps she knowes some danger touching mee.
I'le keepe mine houre.
Sir Harry, a hand a hand to balk you it were siun.
I shall be bold to make your house mine Inne:

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Brother Chartly; I am glad to see you.

lg.l: Mee thinkes sir Harry you looke strangely on mee.
And doe not bid me welcome with an heart.
And blame mee not to looke amazedly,
To see you heare.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Why mee?

lg.l: Come come, y'are welcome.
And now ile turne my strangenesse to true joy,
I am glad to see you well, and safe recovered,
Of your late grievous sicknesse.
The strange amazed lookes that you cast off
You put on mee, and blame mee not to wonder,
That you should talke of sicknesse to sound men,
I thanke my starres, I did not tast the griefe
Of inward paine or outward malady,
This seaven yeeres day.
But by your favour brother,
Then let mee haue my wonder backe againe.
Before I quite part with it, let mee knowe,
Why you the name of brother put vpon mee.
In every clause, a name as strange to mee:
As my recovered sicknesse,
You are plesant,
And it becomes you well, welcome againe,
The rather you are come just to the wedding.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: What wedding sir.

lg.l: That you should aske that question:
Why of my daughter Grace.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Is Grace bestow'd? Of whom I pray,

lg.l: Of whom, but of your sonne.
I wonder brother Chartly, and my friend,
You should thus play on mee.
But by your favour,
Were you tenne Knights Sir Harry, (take mee with you)
My sonne match with your daughter, my consent,
Not worthy to bee crau'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Nay, then I see:
You'l stirre my patience, know this forward match tooke its first birth from you.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: From mee?

lg.l: From you.
Peruse this letter, know you your owne hand.
T'was well that I reseru'd, your hand a witnesse
Against your tongue, you had best denie the Ioynter,
Of the three hundred pounds made to my daughter,
Tis that I know you ayme at, but your seale.
Shall not make mee approue it, I denye
This Seale for mine, nor doe I vouch that hand,
Your daughter and the dower, letter and all
I quite disclaime, sir Harry you much wrong mee.
I can beare more then this, heape wrong on
wrong, and ile support it all, I for this time
Will cast my spleene behind mee, and yet heare mee,
This letter your sonne Chartly as from you,
Delivered mee. I like the motion well.
My spleen is further throwne aside then yours.
And I am full as patient, and yet heare mee;
My sonne's contracted to another maid,
Nay I am patient still, yet that I writ
This letter seald, this impresse I denye.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Why then the jack your hand did counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Why then hee did so, where's that vnthrift speake?

lg.l: Some houre agoe, hee mounted and rid post.
To giue you visit whom hee said lay sicke
Vpon your death-bed.
You amaze mee sir.
It is an ill presage, hereon I see.
Your former salutation tooke its ground:
To see mee safe recovered of my sicknesse.
Indeed it did, your welcome is a subject.
I cannot vse too oft, welcome againe,
I am sorry you this night must sup alone:
For I am else-where cald about some businesse,
Concerning what I know not, howers run on.
I must to Hogsden, high time I were gon.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.

lg.l: Perhaps to the Wisewomans, shee may tell mee.
The fortunes of my sonne, this accident,
Hath bred in mee suspition, and strange feares.
I will not sup alone, but I protest,
'mongst some this night. I'le play the intruding guest.

sp.stage: Exit with his serving-men. Enter the Wisewoman, Sencer, Luce and her Father, 2. Luce.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: But will sir Harry come.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Presume hee will, and Chartly too.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Ile haue the knaue by the eares.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Nay patience sir, leaue your revenge to mee.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Granam I am come according to promise.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: And welcome to the best hole that I haue in Hogsden.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Good even.

lg.l: Thanks sir, a good even may it proue,
That each may reape the fruits of their owne Love:

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: That shall bee my prayer too.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Come what shall's doo.

lg.l: Withdraw, Ile place you all in severall roomes.
Where sit, see, but say nothing.
Heere sweete Mistresse, I know the place well ever
Since I was heere to know my fortune.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: Call mee some halfe an houre hence.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Your Ladiship is most lovingly welcome. A low stoole for the Gentlewoman boy: I made bold to send to you to take view of such a peece of worke, as I presume you haue seldome seene the like.

sp.speaker: Gratia.
sp.p: of whose doing, I pray.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: A friend of yours and mine. Please you withdraw Ile bring you too't.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Wisew.

lg.l: One calls sweet Lady, I shall doe you wrong,
But pray you thinke my little stay not long:

sp.stage: Enter Sencer, sir Harry and Luce.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Here sir in this retyring Chamber.

lg.l: Gramercy friend, how now; whats here to do
A pretty wench and a close chamber too.
That you haue so much grac't my Mothers house,
With your desired presence worthy Knight.
Receiue a poore Maides thanks, who's there? a chayre
And cushin for fir Harry.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Thanks most fayre.

lg.l: Please you but a few minutes heere to stay:
Till my returne, ile not bee long away.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: The gentlewoman will waite on you by and by sir.

lg.l: And ile attend her friend,
Of all those doubts I long to know the end:

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: The Knight you seeke was heere, or will bee streight, and if you bee the man you name your selfe. You are most welcome, and you shall not backe, sill you haue scene sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Gentle youth.
I saw him enter heere, and under priviledge of his acquaintance made I bold to stay.

sp.speaker: 2 Luce.
sp.p: And you are welcome sir, sit downe I pray.

lg.l: Now they are plac't in seuerall roomes, that looke
Into this one. Were Chartly come we had all our company.

sp.speaker: Senser.
sp.p: Harke, there's one knocks 'tis Chartly on my life.

sp.speaker: Luce.

lg.l: One of you let him in whilst I prepare mee
To entertaine his comming.

sp.stage: Enter young Chartly. Vsherd in by Sencer.

lg.l: What? old acquaintance Luce. Not a word?
Yet some lip labour if thou lovest mee.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: My Husband?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: What young Chartly?

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: How? My sonne.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Come, come away with this wailing in woe, if thou putst finger in the eye a little longer, I shall plunge in paine too presently.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O husband, husband.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Husband?

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: What sayst thou my sweete wife,

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Wife? O my hart.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: In that name wife I claime a poore childs part.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O husband; How haue you us'd mee?

lg.l: Nay how doe I meane to use the: But as a man
Should use his wife.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I hope hee doth not meane to use her so.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I hope so too,

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: My granam is a Witch.

sp.speaker: CHart.
sp.p: Nay Luce, sweete wife leaue weeping if thou lou'st mee,

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O can you blame mee, knowing that the fountaine of all these Springs tooke their first head, from you, you know, you too will know, not three daies since are past, since wee were married.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: Married, I can indure no longer.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: It cannot bee.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: It is not possible.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Ile bee even with thee, for this old granam.

lg.l: And though wee wanted witnes vpon earth,
Yet Heaven beares record of our Nuptiall Tye,
Tush, when wee, meete in heaven lets talk of that.
Nay come you asse, you foole, whats past is past,
Though man and wife, yet I must marry nowe.
Another gallant, heere's thy letter Luce.
And this night I intend to lodge with thee.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I'le scratch her eyes out first, although I love her.

lg.l: Prethe bee merry?
I haue made a gull of Grace, and old sir Harry thinks mee
a great way off, I tould the Knight,
My father lay a dying, tooke post,
Rid out of Holburn, turn'd by Islington,
So, hither wench to lodge all night with thee.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Heeres one saith nay to that,

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Was that your journey:

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Why I have too much of Grace already.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Thou hast no grace at all.

lg.l: Nay lets to bed, if thou couldst but imagin how
I loue thee Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: How is it possible you can loue mee, and goe about to marry another.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Dost thou not know shee's rich? Why you foole as soone as I haue got her dower, it is but giuing her a dram, or a pill to purge melancholy to make her turne vp her heeles, and then withall that wealth, come I to liue with thee my sweete raskall.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: Shee thanks you, and is much beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: I am betraide.

lg.l: Art thou my suiter? would'st thou marry mee,
And thy first wife aliue, then poyson mee,
To purchase my poore dowre.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: What shall I say, or thinke, or doe, I am at a Nonplus.

lg.l: Hast thou the face, thou brazen impudence,
To looke vpon mee past grace.
Thou canst not properly call mee past grace, for
I never inioyd thee yet: I cannot tell, whether
I blush or no, but I haue now at this time,
More Grace, then I can tell what to doe with.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: Who drew thee to this folly?

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Who but the old dotard thy Father, who when I was honestly married to a civill maide, hee perswaded mee to leaue her, I was loath at first but after intreating, vrging, and offering mee large proffers, I must confesse I was seduc't to come a wooing to thee.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: My father, villaine.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Ey thy father Grace. And were he heere I would iustifie it to the old dotards face.

lg.l: Vil'd boy thou dar'st not bee so impudent.
When did I meete thee, seeke or sue to thee:
When? Name the day, the month, the houre, the yeare.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Plots, plots. I can but cry you mercy both, Say that I haue done you wrong, I can bee but sorry for it, but indeede to cleare you, and lay the fault where it ought to bee. All this comes from mine owne father in the countrey, who hearing I had married with Luce. Sends mee word of. his blessing to bee divorst from her, and to come a suiter to your daughter, I thinke you haue his hand and seale to show.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: My hand and seale, when was that letter writ.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Heyda, if you get one word more of mee to night, but scurvy lookes, ile giue you leaue to hang mee.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Vilde boy,

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Vngratious villaine.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: Trecherous youth?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: No grace at all?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: No grace.

lg.l: This is bad company who hath reduc't thee?
Speake on my blessing, who hath thus misled thee?
But no more lyes I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Bad company hath bin the shame of mee, I was as vertuously giuen as any youth in Europe, till I fell into one Boysters company, 'tis hee that hath done all the harme vpon mee.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: And if hee should deny it?

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: What then you'd cry him mercy.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: I had best bite out my tongue, and speake no more what shall I doe, or what shall I say, there is no out-facing them all Gentlemen, Fathers, wiues, or what else. I haue wrongd you all. I confesse it that I haue, what would you more, will any of you rayle of mee? Ill beare it, will any of you beate mee? So they strike not too harde Ile suffer it, will any of you challenge mee? Ile answer it. What would you haue mee say, or doo? One of these I have married, the other I haue betrothed, yet both maides for mee; Will you haue mee take one, and leaue the tother? I will, will you haue mee keepe them both? I will.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Periured not mine.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: What you heere too? Nay then I see all my good friends are met together, wilt thou haue mee Luce? I am thy Husband, and had I not lou'd thee better then Grace. I had not disappointed the marriage day to morrow.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Lasciuious no,

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Wilt thou haue mee Grace, for had I not lou'd thee better then Luce. I would never after I had married her bin contracted to thee.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Inconstant no,

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Then neither married man, widdow nor batcheller, whats to bee done? Heeres even the proverbe verifi'd, betweene too stooles, the tayle goes to ground.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Now I bethinke mee this our meeting heere is wondrous strange, call in the Gentlewoman that ownes this house.

div.stage: Enter Sencer and the Wisewoman, Hee like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Old trot, ile trounce thee.
Here is the marriage prou'd twixt Luce and Chartly, witch this was not your promise.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Haue patience, and in the end wee'l pay you all. Your worships are most hartily welcome, I made bold to send for you, and you may see to what end, which was to discover vnto you, the wilde vagaryes of this, of this wanton wag pasty, a wil-doates I warrant him, and sir Harry that your daughter hath scap't this skouring, thanke this gentleman, and then make of him as hee deserues.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: O, I remember him.

lg.l: Hee never pleas'd mine eye so well as now.
I know his Love, and hee in Chartlyes place
My favour shall possesse.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Thanks my sweete Grace.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Ey and the more the inconstant youth to spight.

sp.speaker: Sencer,
sp.p: I gaue her thee in Chartlyes sight.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: There's one gone already, but this is my wife and her ile keepe in spight both of the Devill and his dam.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Not from her lawfull Husband.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: That am I.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: That is the Gentleman, accept him Luce.
And you then like of her, nay Ile make it good,
This gentleman married you visarded, you him disguis'd mistaking him for Chartly, which none but my boy Iack was privy too: after shee chang'd her habit with him, as you with Iack.
And you in mistresse Luces habit.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: May I beleeue you mother.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: This bee your token.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Her that I married, I wrong twice by the finger.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Of that token, my hand was sensible.

lg.l: And ere the clamorous and loud noise bee gone,
I whisperd to her thus.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You are the man,

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Thanks granam, what thou promist thou hast done.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: And leauing him, I take you for my sonne.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Two gone, then wheres the third, this makes mee mad, where is my wife then, for a wife I had.

lg.l: Not see thy wife. Come hither jack my boy.
Nay take him to thee, and with him all joy.
Well art thou seru'd to bee a generall scorne,
To all thy bloud: and if not for our sakes,
For thy soules health and credit of the world,
Haue some regarded to mee, to mee thy father.
Enough sir: if I should say I would become
A new man; You would not take my word.
If I should sweare. I would amend my life,
You would not take mine oath, if I should bind my selfe, to become an honest man you would scarce take my bond.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: I should doe none of these.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Then see sir, when to all your judgements I see me past grace, doe lay hold of Grace, and heere begin to retyre my selfe, this woman hath lent mee a glasse, in which I see all my imperfections, at which my conscience doth more blush inwardly, then my face outwardly, and now I dare confidently vndertake for my selfe I am honest.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Then I dare confidently vndertake to helpe you to a wife who desires to haue an honest man or none, looke on mee well, simple though I stand heere I am your wife, blush not at your folly man, perhaps I haue more in mee, then you expect from mee.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Knavery and riot both which, are now to mee meane forige.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: You and I haue bin better acquainted and yet search mee not too farre least you shame mee, looke on mee well, nay better, better yet, ile assure you I left of a petticoate when I put on these breeches,
What say you now, shee skatters her hayre.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: First loue, and best beloved?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Let me bee both or neither.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: My boy turn'd girle I hope shee'l keepe my counsell from henceforth, ile never entertaine any servant but ile haue her searcht.

lg.l: Her love hath drawne her hither after him.
My loving daughter welcome thou hast runne,
A happy course to see my sonne thus chang'd.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: Father, call mee once againe your sonne, and sir Harry mee your friend: Sencer an hand, and mistresse Grace an hart, in honourable loue. Where I hane wrong'd you Luce forgiue. Impute my errours to my youth not mee, with Grace I interchange, an imbrace with you Luce, a parting busse I wish you all joy, devide my part amongst you, thou my soule.
Nay mother midnight theres some loue for you.
Out of thy folly, beeing reputed wise,
Wee, selfe conceated haue our follyes found:
Beare thou the name of all these comick acts.

lg.l: Luce and Grace, (O covetous man) I see,
I sought to ingrosse what now sufficeth three.
Yet each one wife, enough, one Nuptiall Feast:
Shall serue three Bridalls where, bee thou chiefe guest.

div.head: TO HIS CHOSEN FRIEND, the learned Author Mr Thomas Heywood.
div.l: THou wants no Herald to divulge thy fame;
It needes no Apologie; Only thy name;
Into judicious Readers, doth infuse;
A will: to adde a Lawrell to thy muse;
Was now Maecenas living. How would hee
Support thy learned wit? Whose industry
Hath purchas'd such a knowing skill; That those
Who read admire thee; lesse some Criticke showes
His Ignorance in seeking with new songs,
To gaine the honour; which to thee belongs.
But let pale envie belch forth all her spight
Thy Candid fame shalt still containe white
Vnspotted, pure, and faire, till memory,
Be turn'd obliuion, or a Deity,
Proue mortall; And when Atropos, shall doe
The fatall office, her belongs vnto;
Apollo will rebreath a life in thee,
In length to equall all eternitye
Where in Elyzian joyes hee will so raise
Thy worth where never wither shall the bayes
Wherewith hee crownes thee; So thy works will show.
The Debt, I pay 's no more but what I owe.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
